verses.text: Then Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the LORD, saying, “I will sing to the LORD, for he has triumphed gloriously; the horse and his rider he has thrown into the sea.
verses.comment: This verse closely follows the Hebrew, preserving the poetic form.

verses.text: The LORD is my strength and my song, and he has become my salvation; this is my God, and I will praise him, my father’s God, and I will exalt him.
verses.comment: ‘Song’ and ‘salvation’ match similar phrases in Psalms and Isaiah.

verses.text: The LORD is a warrior; the LORD is his name.
verses.comment: ‘Warrior’ reflects the Hebrew ‘man of war’ in modern language.

verses.text: Pharaoh’s chariots and his army he has cast into the sea; his chosen officers were drowned in the Red Sea.
verses.comment: ‘Cast into the sea’ reflects the metaphor of overwhelming defeat.

verses.text: The depths covered them; they went down into the depths like a stone.
verses.comment: ‘Depths’ is kept as in Hebrew; ‘like a stone’ is literal.

verses.text: Your right hand, O LORD, glorious in power, your right hand, O LORD, shatters the enemy.
verses.comment: 'Right hand' symbolizes strength and action, a common biblical image.

verses.text: And in the greatness of your majesty you overthrow those who rise against you; you send out your fierce anger, it consumes them like stubble.
verses.comment: 'Stubble' preserved as in Hebrew to denote complete destruction.

verses.text: At the blast of your nostrils, the waters piled up; the floods stood upright like a wall; the depths froze in the heart of the sea.
verses.comment: 'Blast of your nostrils' is a literal Hebrew idiom for God's powerful breath.

verses.text: The enemy said, ‘I will pursue, I will overtake, I will divide the spoil; my desire will be satisfied on them. I will draw my sword, my hand will destroy them.’
verses.comment: All direct speech maintained per the original.

verses.text: You blew with your wind; the sea covered them. They sank like lead in the mighty waters.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of Hebrew poetry.

verses.text: Who is like you, O LORD, among the gods? Who is like you—majestic in holiness, awesome in glory, working wonders?
verses.comment: Question format preserved as in Hebrew.

verses.text: You stretched out your right hand; the earth swallowed them.
verses.comment: Short, literal sentence per Hebrew poetry.

verses.text: In your steadfast love you have led the people you redeemed. You have guided them by your strength to your holy dwelling.
verses.comment: 'Steadfast love' translates 'chesed', an important Hebrew term.

verses.text: The peoples have heard; they tremble; anguish has seized the inhabitants of Philistia.
verses.comment: Philistia kept as per historical region.

verses.text: Then the chiefs of Edom were dismayed; trembling seizes the leaders of Moab; all the inhabitants of Canaan have melted away.
verses.comment: 'Melted away' is a literal Hebrew image of fear.

verses.text: Terror and dread fall upon them; by the greatness of your arm they are as still as a stone, until your people, O LORD, pass by, until the people whom you have bought pass by.
verses.comment: 'Bought' here means redeemed or purchased, per the original word.

verses.text: You will bring them in and plant them on the mountain of your inheritance, in the place, O LORD, which you have made for your dwelling, the sanctuary, O Lord, which your hands have established.
verses.comment: 'Mountain of your inheritance' points to Jerusalem and the Temple.

verses.text: The LORD will reign forever and ever.
verses.comment: Short, powerful affirmation. Hebrew structure maintained.

verses.text: For when Pharaoh’s horses with his chariots and his horsemen went into the sea, the LORD brought back the waters of the sea upon them, but the people of Israel walked on dry ground in the midst of the sea.
verses.comment: Follows the narrative of Ex 14:28-29.

verses.text: Then Miriam the prophetess, the sister of Aaron, took a tambourine in her hand, and all the women went out after her with tambourines and dancing.
verses.comment: 'Tambourine' is a common translation for 'tof,' a small hand drum.

verses.text: And Miriam answered them, “Sing to the LORD, for he has triumphed gloriously; the horse and his rider he has thrown into the sea.”
verses.comment: Chorus repeats verse 1.

verses.text: Then Moses led Israel onward from the Red Sea, and they went out into the Wilderness of Shur. They traveled three days in the wilderness and found no water.
verses.comment: ‘Wilderness of Shur’ preserves Hebrew place name.

verses.text: When they came to Marah, they could not drink the waters of Marah because they were bitter; therefore it was named Marah.
verses.comment: ‘Marah’ means ‘bitter’ in Hebrew. Note preserved.

verses.text: And the people grumbled against Moses, saying, “What shall we drink?”
verses.comment: Direct speech and context preserved.

verses.text: And he cried to the LORD, and the LORD showed him a tree, and he threw it into the water, and the water became sweet. There he made for them a statute and a rule, and there he tested them,
verses.comment: Literal rendering. ‘Sweet’ retains the image of making the bitter water drinkable.

verses.text: He said, “If you will diligently listen to the voice of the LORD your God, and do what is right in his eyes, give ear to his commandments and keep all his statutes, I will put none of the diseases on you that I put on the Egyptians, for I am the LORD, your healer.”
verses.comment: ‘Healer’ translates ‘Yahweh Rapha’, the Lord Who Heals.

verses.text: Then they came to Elim, where there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees, and they encamped there by the water.
verses.comment: Numbers and place kept as per historical account.
